name: Identity gate
description: This gate has no theoretical effect.
However, it is useful in physical quantum computers (and as visual aid) to maintain timing.

name: Pauli-\(X\) rotation gate
description: Also known as the "bit-flip" or NOT gate, as it transforms \(\ket{0}\) to \(\ket{1}\) and vice versa.
On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the X axis.
This may be given one or two control qubits. If given two control qubits, it is known as the Toffoli gate.

name: Pauli-\(Y\) rotation gate
description: On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Y axis.
This may be given one control qubit.

name: Pauli-\(Z\) rotation gate
description: The same as an \(X\) gate followed by a \(Y\), this maps \(\ket{0}\) to itself and \(\ket{1}\) to \(-\ket{1}\).
On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Z axis.
This may be given one control qubit.

name: \(S\) phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to half of the \(Z\) gate: a rotation of \(\pi/2\) in the Z axis.

name: \(T\) phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to a quarter of the \(Z\) gate: a rotation of \(\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: \(T^\dagger\) phase-shift gate
description: The opposite of the \(T\) gate: a rotation of \(-\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: Qubit-swap gate
description: Swaps two qubit values between registers.
This may be given one control qubit, where it is sometimes known as the Fredkin gate.
